{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3170816,"name":"Yiğit ","username":"Yigit","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/yigit/{size}/254511_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-22T23:15:40.999Z","cooked":"

We are using SDS MK4 L2 Wheels with NEO Motors
Today, we took out all of our swerve modules to grease them, and mounted them back with swerve guards. After mounting them, we encountered an issue with our front left module.

So, we put our robot on wooden blocks so it’s not touching the floor. When we tell the robot to go forward, (with a joystick input AND in autonomous) all wheels comply except for the front left module.

No matter how big the input is, it will not DRIVE unless we give it a little push physically. With the slightest amount of push by hand, it drives well just like the 3 other modules. The turning motor works fine also, only the driving is not functioning.

Do you have any idea what’s going on here? There have been 0 changes in the code also.

Sounds like one the the three wires from the spark max to the neo has a bad connection. If you are using Anderson connectors I would start there.

Also less likely option could be a dead phase in the motor, this could’ve if you lacked any current limit on the motor and stalled it.

One thing to check would be the key on the drive motor. If the retaining clip is not lined up correctly the key could slip past it causing the gear to spin on the shaft.

It can also be a loose or broken encoder wire

You were right, we found out one of the connectors had a loose contact, we just replaced it and it works as intended now. Thanks!
